_exec_summary.SummaryText:
HARLAN BAKERIES - GT, LLC

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM PLAN
Executive Summary


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at Harlan Bakeries - GT Indianapolis, Indiana facility are engrained in the fundamentals of the process safety prevention program.

At the Indianapolis, Indiana facility anhydrous ammonia is kept in inventory and is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The same properties that make this chemical valuable as a refrigerant also make it necessary to observe specific safety precautions.  These safety precautions are exercised in the operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system to control human environmental exposure in an effort to reduce the overall threat to workers as well as the surrounding communities.

It is Harlan's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws, rules, and regulations.  However, the safe handling of ammonia is paramount.  Standards and recommended practices governing the safe handling of ammonia are used to ensure that a reasonable level of risk reduction is maintained.  Investigation of inherently safer technologies, and failsafe design applications are a few of the continuous improvements being studied.  Safety depends upon management commitment, the manner in which ammonia refrigerant is handled, the safety devices inherent to the refrigeration system design, operating procedures and philosophies, and the training of workers.

Harlan believes that accountability for safety reaches throughout all levels of management.  Senior management's commitment and dedication to continued safe-operating practices is clearly evident in organization structure and employee empowerment.  

Extensive improvements have been made to safety and health programs like the prevention program (process safety and risk management), emergency preparedness and response, and training.

Additionally, Harlan believe

s employee involvement is the cornerstone to continued safe operations.  This is known as employee ownership and its success is portrayed through lower injury rates, fewer incidents, and improved efficiencies at the plant.
 

The Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan outlines procedures for warned and unwarned emergencies that may occur at the plant.  Warned emergencies are usually tornadoes, heavy snowstorms, or conditions that are reasonably predictable.  Unwarned emergencies usually consist of onsite emergencies such as a spill, fire/explosion, or a chemical release.  As a responsible company, Harlan coordinates emergency response activities and training with the local emergency management organizations.  This ensures prompt mitigation actions during incidents.

Facility description and regulated substances handled

Harlan Bakeries - GT is a domestic producer of processed food products.  The Indianapolis, Indiana plant site covers approximately 5 acres and the facility grounds are approximately 34 total acres within the Indianapolis City limits.  It is located at 7575 Georgetown Road in Indianapolis, Indiana, Marion County.

There are approximately 120 employees at the plant site. 

Only one chemical covered by 40 CFR Part 68 is inventoried at the Indianapolis site.  This substance is present in quantities greater than the threshold quantity identified by the RMP regulation and therefore is included in our risk management program.

Ammonia (anhydrous)- Ammonia is used as a refrigerant at the plant.  It is received into the plant by truck, however deliveries of ammonia are infrequent.  

Accidental release program & chemical-specific prevention steps                                                                
                                                                                                                                                                                          Harlan contracted with an outside consulting firm to assist in the

refinement of the prevention program tailored exclusively to ammonia refrigeration operations.  This prevention program was designed around mechanical integrity and training aspects.  The primary objective of the prevention program is to ensure complete containment of ammonia through safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system.

The plant has completed a process hazard analysis (PHA) of the modified ammonia refrigeration system.  The recommendations generated during this review were prioritized using a standardized Risk Rank Matrix method.

Five year accident history

Harlan has a very comprehensive Incident Reporting and Investigation procedural process.  This process is defined and explained in the prevention program procedures.  Basically, an incident occurs when a deviation from expected performance is experienced.

Individuals knowledgeable in refrigeration operation or the equipment being investigated lead formal incident investigations.  Root cause and corrective actions are determined and formal reports are prepared.  Progress regarding corrective action on all investigated incidents is tracked through final resolution.

The plant has not had an accidental release of ammonia within the past five years that resulted in an onsite injury or adversely affected the community.


Emergency response Program

The plant's emergency action plan has been designed to address likely incidents arising from our ammonia refrigeration system.  The emergency plan is a vital part of the overall prevention program.   Harlan continues to plan for the unplanned ammonia release while striving to adhere to the latest mechanical integrity and inherently safer technologies.


Planned improvements to reduce risk

In accordance with its risk management program, the plant conducts continuous self-examination evaluations designed to identify and assess process/operational risk employees and the community.  One of the primary aspects of the risk management program is the em
powerment of each employee with the responsibility for continuous safe operations.
